entities.description: Gebhard of Lahngau, of the Conradine dynasty, son of Odo, count of Lahngau, and Judith, was himself count of Wetterau (909–910) and Rheingau (897–906) and then duke of Lotharingia (Lorraine).

heading: Deaths
txt: Gerhard I, Frankish nobleman

heading: Deaths
txt: Qian Hongzuo, king of Wuyue (b. 928)

entities.title: Qian Hongzuo
entities.description: Qian Hongzuo, courtesy name Yuanyou (元祐), formally King Zhongxian of Wuyue (吳越忠獻王), possibly with the temple name of Chengzong (成宗), was the third king (王) of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms Period state Wuyue.

entities.title: Wuyue
entities.description: Wuyue, 907–978, was an independent coastal kingdom founded during the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period (907–960) of Chinese history. It was ruled by the Qian family, whose family name remains widespread in the kingdom's former territory.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leo Passianos, Byzantine general

entities.title: Leo Passianos
entities.description: Leo Passianos was the Byzantine general sent by the Catapan of Italy Leo Tornikios Kontoleon to fight the Lombard rebel Melus of Bari in 1017. He is not to be confused with the other Passianos killed in Melus' first rebellion while fighting the Saracens under Ishmael of Montepeloso.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger I of Sicily, Norman nobleman (b. 1031)

entities.title: Roger I of Sicily
entities.description: Roger I, nicknamed Roger Bosso and The Great Count, was a Norman nobleman who became the first Count of Sicily from 1071 to 1101. He was a member of the House of Hauteville, and his descendants in the male line continued to rule Sicily down to 1194.

heading: Deaths
txt: Innocent V, pope of the Catholic Church (b. 1225)

entities.title: Pope Innocent V
entities.description: Pope Innocent V, born Pierre de Tarentaise, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 21 January to 22 June 1276. A member of the Order of Preachers, he acquired a reputation as an effective preacher. He held one of the two "Dominican Chairs" at the university of Paris, and was instrumental in helping with drawing up the "program of studies" for the Order. In 1269, Peter o

heading: Deaths
txt: Aimone, Count of Savoy (b. 1291)

entities.title: Aimone, Count of Savoy
entities.description: Aymon, nicknamed the Peaceful, was Count of Savoy from 1329 to 1343.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jamshīd al-Kāshī, Persian astronomer and mathematician (b. 1380)

entities.title: Jamshīd al-Kāshī
entities.description: Ghiyāth al-Dīn Jamshīd Masʿūd al-Kāshī was a Persian astronomer and mathematician during the reign of Tamerlane.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonardo Loredan, Italian politician, 76th Doge of Venice (b. 1436)

entities.title: Leonardo Loredan
entities.description: Leonardo Loredan was the 75th doge of the Republic of Venice from 1501 until his death in 1521. His dogeship was one of the most important in the history of Venice.

entities.title: Doge of Venice
entities.description: The Doge of Venice, sometimes translated as Duke, was the chief magistrate and leader of the Republic of Venice between 726 and 1797.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Fisher, English bishop and saint (b. 1469)

entities.title: John Fisher
entities.description: John Fisher was an English Catholic bishop, cardinal, and theologian. Fisher was also an academic, and eventually served as Chancellor of the University of Cambridge. He was canonized a saint by Pope Pius XI.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Whitelocke, English judge and politician, Chief Justice of Chester (b. 1570)

entities.title: James Whitelocke
entities.description: Sir James Whitelocke SL was an English judge and politician who sat in the House of Commons between 1610 and 1622.

entities.title: Chief Justice of Chester
entities.description: The Justice of Chester was the chief judicial authority for the county palatine of Chester, from the establishment of the county until the abolition of the Great Sessions in Wales and the palatine judicature in 1830.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann von Aldringen, Austrian field marshal (b. 1588)

entities.title: Johann von Aldringen
entities.description: Johann Reichsgraf von Aldringen was an Austrian soldier active before and during the Thirty Years' War. He was born in Luxembourg in the Duchy of Luxembourg, and after travelling as a nobleman's page in France, Italy and the Netherlands, he went to the University of Paris.

heading: Deaths
txt: Katherine Philips, Anglo-Welsh poet (b. 1631)

entities.title: Katherine Philips
entities.description: Katherine or Catherine Philips, also known as "The Matchless Orinda", was an Anglo-Welsh royalist poet, translator, and woman of letters. She achieved renown as a translator of Pierre Corneille's Pompée and Horace, and for her editions of poetry after her death. She was highly regarded by many notable later writers, including John Dryden and John Keats, as being influential.

heading: Deaths
txt: Josiah Child, English merchant, economist, and politician (b. 1630)

entities.title: Josiah Child
entities.description: Sir Josiah Child, 1st Baronet,, was an English economist, merchant and politician. He was an economist proponent of mercantilism and governor of the East India Company. He led the company in the Anglo-Mughal War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Matthew Henry, Welsh minister and author (b. 1662)

entities.title: Matthew Henry
entities.description: Matthew Henry was a Nonconformist minister and author, who was born in Wales but spent much of his life in England. He is best known for the six-volume biblical commentary Exposition of the Old and New Testaments.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlo Zimech, Maltese priest and painter (b. 1696)

entities.title: Carlo Zimech
entities.description: Don Carlo Zimech was a Maltese priest and painter. He was born within a well-off family in Żebbuġ on mainland Malta. In his later life, he retired to Nadur, Gozo, possibly because of health problems. He died in his residence on 22 June 1766, and was buried in the Nadur parish church.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heber C. Kimball, American religious leader (b. 1801)

entities.title: Heber C. Kimball
entities.description: Heber Chase Kimball was a leader in the early Latter Day Saint movement. He served as one of the original twelve apostles in the early Church of the Latter Day Saints, and as first counselor to Brigham Young in the First Presidency of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints for more than two decades, from 1847 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rudecindo Alvarado, Argentinian general (b. 1792)

entities.title: Rudecindo Alvarado
entities.description: Rudecindo Alvarado was an Argentine general. He fought in the military campaigns of Manuel Belgrano, and in the Army of the Andes. He was governor of Mendoza. He left the country during the rule of Juan Manuel de Rosas, and returned in 1852 after Rosas' defeat at the battle of Caseros.

heading: Deaths
txt: Howard Staunton, English chess player (b. 1810)

entities.title: Howard Staunton
entities.description: Howard Staunton was an English chess master who is generally regarded as the world's strongest player from 1843 to 1851, largely as a result of his 1843 victory over Pierre Charles Fournier de Saint-Amant. He promoted a chess set of clearly distinguishable pieces of standardised shape – the Staunton pattern promulgated by Nathaniel Cooke – that is still the style required for competitions. He was

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Ossian Bonnet, French mathematician and academic (b. 1819)

entities.title: Pierre Ossian Bonnet
entities.description: Pierre Ossian Bonnet was a French mathematician. He made some important contributions to the differential geometry of surfaces, including the Gauss–Bonnet theorem.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexandre-Antonin Taché, Canadian archbishop and missionary (b. 1823)

entities.title: Alexandre-Antonin Taché
entities.description: Alexandre-Antonin Taché, O.M.I., was a Canadian Roman Catholic priest, missionary of the Oblate order, author and the first Archbishop of Saint Boniface in Manitoba, Canada.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis Lubbock, American colonel and politician, 9th Governor of Texas (b. 1815)

entities.title: Francis Lubbock
entities.description: Francis Richard Lubbock was the ninth Governor of Texas and was in office during the American Civil War. He was the brother of Thomas Saltus Lubbock, for whom Lubbock County, Texas, and the eponymous county seat are named.

entities.title: List of Governors of Texas
entities.description: The governor of Texas is the chief executive of the U.S. State of Texas, the presiding officer over the executive branch of the Government of Texas, and the commander-in-chief of the Texas National Guard, the state's militia. The governor has the power to consider bills passed by the Texas Legislature, by signing them into law, or vetoing them, and in bills relating to appropriations, the power of

heading: Deaths
txt: Ștefan Octavian Iosif, Romanian poet and translator (b. 1875)

entities.title: Ștefan Octavian Iosif
entities.description: Ştefan Octavian Iosif was a Romanian poet and translator of Romanian origin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Felix Klein, German mathematician and academic (b. 1849)

entities.title: Felix Klein
entities.description: Christian Felix Klein was a German mathematician and mathematics educator, known for his work with group theory, complex analysis, non-Euclidean geometry, and on the associations between geometry and group theory. His 1872 Erlangen program, classifying geometries by their basic symmetry groups, was an influential synthesis of much of the mathematics of the time.

heading: Deaths
txt: A. B. Frost, American illustrator and painter (b. 1851)

entities.title: A. B. Frost
entities.description: Arthur Burdett Frost, usually cited as A. B. Frost, was an American illustrator, graphic artist and comics writer. He was also well known as a painter. Frost's work is well known for its dynamic representation of motion and sequence. Frost is considered one of the great illustrators in the "Golden Age of American Illustration". Frost illustrated over 90 books and produced hundreds of paintings; in

heading: Deaths
txt: Armand Fallières, French politician, 9th President of France (b. 1841)

entities.title: Armand Fallières
entities.description: Clément Armand Fallières was a French statesman who was President of France from 1906 to 1913.

entities.title: President of France
entities.description: The president of France, officially the president of the French Republic, is the head of state and head of executive of France as well as the commander-in-chief of the French Armed Forces. The French presidency is the supreme magistracy of the country, and the president is the holder of the highest office in France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tim Birkin, English racing driver and lieutenant (b. 1896)

entities.title: Tim Birkin
entities.description: Sir Henry Ralph Stanley "Tim" Birkin, 3rd Baronet was a British racing driver, one of the "Bentley Boys" of the 1920s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Szymon Askenazy, Polish historian and diplomat (b. 1866)

entities.title: Szymon Askenazy
entities.description: Szymon Askenazy was a Jewish-Polish historian, educator, statesman and diplomat, founder of the Askenazy school.

heading: Deaths
txt: Moritz Schlick, German-Austrian physicist and philosopher (b. 1882)

entities.title: Moritz Schlick
entities.description: Friedrich Albert Moritz Schlick was a German philosopher, physicist, and the founding father of logical positivism and the Vienna Circle.

heading: Deaths
txt: C. J. Dennis, Australian poet and author (b. 1876)

entities.title: C. J. Dennis
entities.description: Clarence Michael James Stanislaus Dennis, better known as C. J. Dennis, was an Australian poet known for his humorous poems, especially "The Songs of a Sentimental Bloke", published in the early 20th century. Though Dennis's work is less well known today, his 1915 publication of The Sentimental Bloke sold 65,000 copies in its first year, and by 1917 he was the most prosperous poet in Australian hi

heading: Deaths
txt: Monty Noble, Australian cricketer and sportscaster (b. 1873)

entities.title: Monty Noble
entities.description: Montague Alfred Noble was an Australian cricketer who played for New South Wales and Australia. A right-hand batsman, right-handed bowler who could deliver both medium pace and off-break bowling, capable fieldsman and tactically sound captain, Noble is considered as one of the great Australian all-rounders. He scored 13,975 first class runs between 1893 and 1920 and took 624 wickets. He made 37 ce

heading: Deaths
txt: August Froehlich, German priest and activist (b. 1891)

entities.title: August Froehlich
entities.description: August Froehlich was a German-Silesian Roman Catholic priest. In his pastoral activity he opposed National Socialism. He campaigned in the name of German Catholics and of Polish forced labourers. He died in Dachau concentration camp.

heading: Deaths
txt: Isamu Chō, Japanese general (b. 1895)

entities.title: Isamu Chō
entities.description: Isamu Chō   was an officer in the Imperial Japanese Army known for his support of ultranationalist politics and involvement in a number of attempted coup d'états in pre-World War II Japan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mitsuru Ushijima, Japanese general (b. 1887)

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter de la Mare, English poet, short story writer and novelist (b. 1873)

entities.title: Walter de la Mare
entities.description: Walter John de la Mare was an English poet, short story writer, and novelist. He is probably best remembered for his works for children, for his poem "The Listeners", and for a highly acclaimed selection of subtle psychological horror stories, amongst them "Seaton's Aunt" and "All Hallows".

heading: Deaths
txt: Hermann Brill, German educator and politician, 8th Minister-President of Thuringia (b. 1895)

entities.title: Hermann Brill
entities.description: Dr. Hermann Louis Brill was a German doctor of law and a politician (SPD).

entities.title: List of Ministers-President of Thuringia
entities.description: The office of Minister-President of Thuringia was established at the state's first formation in 1920. On 23 July 1952 the state, then part of the socialist German Democratic Republic, was abolished. On 3 October 1990, the state was re-established and joined the Federal Republic of Germany; since then it has been one of the country's sixteen constituent states (Länder).

heading: Deaths
txt: Havank, Dutch journalist and author (b. 1904)

entities.title: Havank
entities.description: Havank, pseudonym of Hendrikus Frederikus (Hans) van der Kallen, was a Dutch writer, journalist, and translator. He published over 30 crime novels and is considered one of the founding fathers of the Dutch detective genre.

heading: Deaths
txt: David O. Selznick, American screenwriter and producer (b. 1902)

entities.title: David O. Selznick
entities.description: David O. Selznick was an American film producer, screenwriter and film studio executive. He is best known for producing Gone with the Wind (1939) and Rebecca (1940), both of which earned him an Academy Award for Best Picture.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thaddeus Shideler, American hurdler (b. 1883)

entities.title: Thaddeus Shideler
entities.description: Thaddeus "Thad" Rutter Shideler was an American hurdler who competed in the early twentieth century. He competed in athletics at the 1904 Summer Olympics and won a silver medal in the 110 meters hurdles. Fred Schule won the gold medal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Judy Garland, American actress and singer (b. 1922)

entities.title: Judy Garland
entities.description: Judy Garland was an American actress, singer, vaudevillian, and dancer. With a career spanning 45 years, she attained international stardom as an actress in both musical and dramatic roles, as a recording artist, and on the concert stage. Renowned for her versatility, she received an Academy Juvenile Award, a Golden Globe Award, and a Special Tony Award. Garland was the first woman to win the Gram

heading: Deaths
txt: Đặng Thùy Trâm, Vietnamese surgeon and author (b. 1942)

entities.title: Đặng Thùy Trâm
entities.description: Đặng Thùy Trâm was a Vietnamese doctor. She worked as a battlefield surgeon for the People's Army of Vietnam and Vietcong during the Vietnam War. Her wartime diaries, which chronicle the last two years of her life, attracted international attention following their publication in 2005.

heading: Deaths
txt: Darius Milhaud, French composer and educator (b. 1892)

entities.title: Darius Milhaud
entities.description: Darius Milhaud was a French composer, conductor, and teacher. He was a member of Les Six—also known as The Group of Six—and one of the most prolific composers of the 20th century. His compositions are influenced by jazz and Brazilian music and make extensive use of polytonality. Milhaud is considered one of the key modernist composers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacqueline Audry, French director and screenwriter (b. 1908)

entities.title: Jacqueline Audry
entities.description: Jacqueline Audry was a French film director who began making films in post-World War II France and specialised in literary adaptations. She was the first commercially successful female director of post-war France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Laughner, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (Rocket From the Tombs and Pere Ubu) (b. 1952)

entities.title: Rocket From the Tombs
entities.description: Rocket from the Tombs is an American rock band originally active from mid-1974 to mid-1975 in Cleveland, Ohio, United States. The band was reconstituted several times with various line-ups starting in 2003.

entities.title: Pere Ubu
entities.description: Pere Ubu is an American rock group formed in Cleveland, Ohio, in 1975. Despite a variety of long-term and recurring band members, singer David Thomas is the only constant. They released their debut album The Modern Dance in 1978 and followed with several more LPs before disbanding in 1982. Thomas reformed the group in 1987, continuing to record and tour.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Chiron, Monégasque race car driver (b. 1899)

entities.title: Louis Chiron
entities.description: Louis Alexandre Chiron was a Monégasque racing driver who competed in rallies, sports car races, and Grands Prix.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Losey, American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1909)

entities.title: Joseph Losey
entities.description: Joseph Walton Losey III was an American theatre and film director, producer, and screenwriter. Born in Wisconsin, he studied in Germany with Bertolt Brecht and then returned to the United States. Blacklisted by Hollywood in the 1950s, he moved to Europe where he made the remainder of his films, mostly in the United Kingdom. Among the most critically and commercially successful were the films with

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Astaire, American actor and dancer (b. 1899)

entities.title: Fred Astaire
entities.description: Fred Astaire was an American actor, dancer, singer, choreographer, and television presenter. He is widely considered the most influential dancer in the history of film.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dennis Day, American singer and actor (b. 1916)

entities.title: Dennis Day
entities.description: Dennis Day was an American singer, radio, television, and film personality, and comedian. He was of Irish descent.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ilya Frank, Russian physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1908)

entities.title: Ilya Frank
entities.description: Ilya Mikhailovich Frank was a Soviet winner of the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1958 jointly with Pavel Alekseyevich Cherenkov and Igor Y. Tamm, also of the Soviet Union. He received the award for his work in explaining the phenomenon of Cherenkov radiation. He received the Stalin prize in 1946 and 1953 and the USSR state prize in 1971.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Pat Nixon, American educator, 37th First Lady of the United States (b. 1912)

entities.title: Pat Nixon
entities.description: Thelma Catherine "Pat" Nixon, also commonly known as Patricia Nixon, was an American educator and the wife of Richard Nixon, the 37th President of the United States. During her more than 30 years in public life, she served as both the Second (1953–1961) and First Lady of the United States (1969–1974).

entities.title: First Lady of the United States
entities.description: First Lady of the United States (FLOTUS) is the title held by the hostess of the White House, usually the wife of the president of the United States, concurrent with the president's term in office. Although the first lady's role has never been codified or officially defined, she figures prominently in the political and social life of the United States. Since the early 20th century, the first lady

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonid Derbenyov, Russian poet and songwriter (b. 1931)

entities.title: Leonid Derbenyov
entities.description: Leonid Petrovich Derbenyov was a Russian poet and lyricist widely regarded as one of the stalwarts of the 20th century Soviet and Russian pop music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Al Hansen, American sculptor and author (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ted Gärdestad, Swedish singer-songwriter (b. 1956)

entities.title: Ted Gärdestad
entities.description: Ted Arnbjörn Gärdestad was a Swedish singer, songwriter, musician and actor known internationally as Ted. Gärdestad began his acting career in 1966 and began playing music in 1971, signing with Polar Music. Assigned with in-house producers Benny Andersson and Björn Ulvaeus, Gärdestad released his first single, "Hela världen runt," in late 1971 and worked closely with the four members of ABBA to cr

heading: Deaths
txt: Gérard Pelletier, Canadian journalist and politician (b. 1919)

heading: Deaths
txt: Vasil Bykaŭ, Belarusian war novelist (b. 1924)

entities.title: Vasil Bykaŭ
entities.description: Vasíl Uładzímiravič Býkaŭ was a prolific Belarusian author of novels and novellas about World War II and a significant figure in Soviet and Belarusian literature and civic thought. His work earned him endorsements for the Nobel Prize nomination from, among others, Nobel Prize laureates Joseph Brodsky and Czesław Miłosz.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bob Bemer, American computer scientist and engineer (b. 1920)

entities.title: Bob Bemer
entities.description: Robert William Bemer was a computer scientist best known for his work at IBM during the late 1950s and early 1960s. His motto was:

heading: Deaths
txt: Mattie Stepanek, American poet and author (b. 1990)

heading: Deaths
txt: Erik Parlevliet, Dutch field hockey player (b. 1964)

entities.title: Erik Parlevliet
entities.description: Erik Robert Parlevliet was a Dutch field hockey player, who earned a total number of 155 caps, scoring 47 goals.

heading: Deaths
txt: Natalia Bekhtereva, Russian neuroscientist and psychologist (b. 1924)

entities.title: Natalia Bekhtereva
entities.description: Natalia Petrovna Bekhtereva was a Soviet and Russian neuroscientist and psychologist who developed neurophysiological approaches to psychology, such as measuring the impulse activity of human neurons. She was a participant in the documentary films The Call of the Abyss and Storm of Consciousness, which aroused wide public interest. Candidate of Biological Sciences, Doctor of Medicine, Full Profess

heading: Deaths
txt: George Carlin, American comedian, actor, and author (b. 1937)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dody Goodman, American actress and dancer (b. 1914)

heading: Deaths
txt: Coşkun Özarı, Turkish footballer and coach (b. 1931)

entities.title: Coşkun Özarı
entities.description: Coşkun Özarı was a Turkish football player and coach.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juan Luis Galiardo, Spanish actor and producer (b. 1922)

entities.title: Juan Luis Galiardo
entities.description: Juan Luis Galiardo Comes was a Spanish television, theater and film actor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henning Larsen, Danish architect, designed the Copenhagen Opera House (b. 1925)

entities.title: Henning Larsen
entities.description: Henning Larsen, Hon. FAIA was a Danish architect. He is internationally known for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs building in Riyadh and the Copenhagen Opera House.

entities.title: Copenhagen Opera House
entities.description: The Copenhagen Opera House is the national opera house of Denmark, and among the most modern opera houses in the world. It is also one of the most expensive opera houses ever built at a cost of 2.5 billion DKK. It is located on the island of Holmen in central Copenhagen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Allan Simonsen, Danish race car driver (b. 1978)

heading: Deaths
txt: Fouad Ajami, Lebanese-American author and academic (b. 1945)

entities.title: Fouad Ajami
entities.description: Fouad A. Ajami was a MacArthur Fellowship winning, Lebanese-born American university professor and writer on Middle Eastern issues. He was a senior fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rama Narayanan, Indian director and producer (b. 1949)

heading: Deaths
txt: James Horner, American composer and conductor (b. 1953)

entities.title: James Horner
entities.description: James Roy Horner was an American composer, conductor and orchestrator of film scores. He was known for the integration of choral and electronic elements, and for his frequent use of motifs associated with Celtic music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mao Kobayashi, Japanese newscaster and actress (b. 1982)

entities.title: Mao Kobayashi (actress)
entities.description: Mao Kobayashi  was a Japanese freelance newscaster and actress. She was also one of Fuji TV's weathercasters.

heading: Deaths
txt: Quett Masire, Botswanan politician (b. 1926)

heading: Deaths
txt: Vinnie Paul, American musician (b. 1964)

entities.title: Vinnie Paul
entities.description: Vincent Paul Abbott, also known as Vinnie Paul, was an American musician, songwriter and producer, best known for being the drummer and co-founder of the heavy metal band Pantera. He was a member of Hellyeah for 12 years from 2006 until his death in 2018. He also co-founded the heavy metal band Damageplan in 2003 with his younger brother, Dimebag Darrell.
